subject: VMware: raise more specific exceptions
commit_message:
VMware: raise more specific exceptions

In certain cases the exception handling for backend errors
would be handled too broadly. This patch elevates the backend exception
to the application so that it can treat specific errors.

In the application we can now handle the following specific exceptions:
- FileAlreadyExists - for example when moving a directory to a directory
that already exists
- InvalidProperty - for example when using neutron and opaque networks
are not supported
- AlreadyExists - for example a port group already exists
- NotAuthenticated - for example the operation is denied as because a
session is not established
- CannotDeleteFile - the file cannot be deleted
- FileFault - a file access exception
- FileLocked - an attempt is made to lock a file that is
already in use
- FileNotFound - the specific file does not exist

Change-Id: I789165f3879ec5df73f72c2737377e0fcfc99656

subject: Normalize Scheduler Weights
commit_message:
Normalize Scheduler Weights

Currently we are using the raw values directly from the available
weighers instead of normalizing them. This makes difficult to
properly use multipliers for establishing the relative importance
between two weighters (one big magnitude will shade a smaller one).

Changes introduced in this commit:
1) It introduces weight normalization so that we can apply multipliers
easily. All the weights for an object will be normalized between 0.0
and 1.0 before being sumed up, so that the final weight for a host
will be:

weight = w1_multiplier * norm(w1) + w2_multiplier * norm(w2) + ...

2) base_weight.BaseWeigher has been changed into an ABC so that we
enforce that all weighers have the expected methods.

3) base_weight.BaseWeigher.weigh_objects() does no longer sum up the
computer weighs to the object, but it rather returns a list that will
be then normalized and added to the existing weight by BaseWeightHandler.

4) Change _weight_multiplier() to weight_multiplier() as a public method

Port from I81bf90898d3cb81541f4390596823cc00106eb20
Related to bp nova-oslo-scheduler

subject: Support If-[None-]Match for object HEAD, SLO, and DLO
commit_message:
Support If-[None-]Match for object HEAD, SLO, and DLO

I moved the checking of If-Match and If-None-Match out of the object
server's GET method and into swob so that everyone can use it. The
interface is similar to the Range handling; make a response with
conditional_response=True, and you get handing of If-Match and
If-None-Match.

Since the only users of conditional_response are object GET, object
HEAD, SLO, and DLO, this has the effect of adding support for If-Match
and If-None-Match to just the latter three places and nowhere
else. This makes object GET and HEAD consistent for any kind of
object, large or small.

This also fixes a bug where various conditional headers (If-*) were
passed through to the object server on segment requests, which could
cause segment requests to fail with a 304 or 412 response. Now only
certain headers are copied to the segment requests, and that doesn't
include the conditional ones, so they can't goof up the segment
retrieval.

Note that I moved SegmentedIterable to swift.common.request_helpers
because it sprouted a transitive dependency on swob, and leaving it in
utils caused a circular import.

Bonus fix: unified the handling of DiskFileQuarantined and
DiskFileNotFound in object server GET and HEAD. Now in either case, a
412 will be returned if the client said "If-Match: *". If not, the
response is a 404, just like before.

Closes-Bug: 1279076
Closes-Bug: 1280022
Closes-Bug: 1280028

subject: Nova baremetal: use mkfs/rsync instead of dd
commit_message:
Nova baremetal: use mkfs/rsync instead of dd

The Nova baremetal-deploy-helper utility currently uses dd
to copy the root partition data from the compute host to
the instance being deployed.

With dd we blast out our pre-made filesystem to each disk
and then use resize2fs to grow it to the actual size of the root
partition on first boot.

This is causing some subtle file system problems and chicken/egg sorts
of issues with images:

1) It forces us know something about how large disk will be
when you build your images. By default ext4 file systems can
only be resized up to a certain amount (by a factor of around 1000 or so).
So if your file system is really large you could hit this limit
on first boot w/ resize2fs.

2) We currently have a hack around #1 above by setting the max-online-resize
option for mkfs.ext4 to something really large. By doing this today
we allow for root partitions up to 1PB (fairly large).

3) In general #2 works but we are hitting some intermittent resize2fs
issues: See, https://bugs.launchpad.net/diskimage-builder/+bug/1280709
Also #2 has a cost in that your file system layout and size aren't
ideal.

---------

In this patch we swap out dd and use mkfs directly on the root partition
and then use rsync to copy data. This allows us to avoid quirky
issues with ext4 resizing which really weren't intended to be used like
we are currently using them (resizing a 2G file system up to a 1PB
is not what the file system designers had in mind here)

In my tests the entire mkfs/rsync function is around 15-20 percent
faster than the old dd function as well.

Closes-bug: 1280709
Change-Id: Ia71f8bbb59637fd20e35db958e4fb92262e071bc

subject: Add support for location parameters in v2 commands
commit_message:
Add support for location parameters in v2 commands

Currently glanceclient's v2 commands don't support modification
operations on an image's location attribute - the argparse specification
for the location attribute of the image-update command causes the image
id argument to be included in list of locations and so the command
parsing fails (because it causes the image id to appear to be missing).

Furthermore even if the 'locations' argument were to be accepted by
argparse (e.g. by changing the argument specs and using --id to specify
the image id) the command would still fail because the arguments are
passed directly to the schema which expects the value of the 'locations'
argument to be a valid dictionary (there is nobody to convert the
argument string to a python dictionary that the schema expects).

This commit overrides the default 'locations' parameter definition
(which is inferred from the image schema) and instead provides
(simplified) operations on 'locations' via a set of parameters:

    *) Instead of allowing multiple locations to be added on the command
       line at most one location can be added per invocation on the
       command line using the '--location' option.

    *) The metadata for the location being added can be optionally
       specified using the '--metadata' option.

    *) An existing location can be removed using the '--remove-location'
       option. This option can be used multiple times in one invocation
       to remove multiple locations.

    *) The '--location' option can also be invoked to modify the
       metadata for an existing url. However, due to the way the glance
       server is implemented, one cannot modify only one url in the
       location list - the entire 'locations' attribute must be first
       cleared and then set to the new value.

       This will result in two requests - one to clear the existing set
       of locations and the second to set it to the new value. The
       update operation is therefore NOT atomic. This needs to be fixed
       once the server provides a (true) location update API.

The v2 'image' and 'shell' related tests have also been supplemented.

Note that in order to use these options the server must be first
configured to expose location related info to the clients (i.e.
'show_multiple_locations' must be set to 'True").

Change-Id: Ibe85b192b2f40bb1b81bf6136897ded2bfc363ff
Closes-bug: #1271452
